intro: Lappula texana var. coronata, commonly known as the Texas lappula, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is a member of the Papaveraceae family, which includes poppies and other flowering plants. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid environments. Its flowers are small and clustered, often with a distinctive corona-like structure around the stamens. It is characterized by its basal leaves and its ability to thrive in harsh, semi-desert conditions.
